Dear Mr. Derscheid:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
May 30, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action
plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6692.
Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an initial treatment plan for each resident within 30
calendar days of admission.
2

One of three youth requiring an initial treatment plan during this period under
review was submitted thirteen days late.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental follow
up that is needed, have been reviewed with the resident
and with the parent and with the responsible case
manager.
Two of four discharged files did not include a statement or documentation that the
discharge plan was reviewed with the resident, parent, and responsible
caseworker.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Pineview program for open short-term youth has not established an ongoing
clothing inventory. The youth wear their personal clothing the day they enter the
program, they are then given "program clothing" to wear during the week and the
youth then wear their personal clothing home on the weekend. The youth come
back to the program on Monday's and typically have a different outfit on and turn
that outfit in until they go home for the weekend again on Friday. The youth go on
home passes each weekend and so the facility only hold the youth clothing
Monday through Friday. Pineview administration was given assistance on
developing a log or document to indicate what the youth are wearing each time
they leave or reenter the facility.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency did not require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
3

The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had five special investigations during this period under review with four
resulting in corrective action plans. The facility’s corrective action plan compliance
is monitored quarterly, and they have completed all current corrective action plans.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the facility’s budget
and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance
Pineview completed a PREA audit on April 18, 2022. The facility was found in
noncompliance with 27 areas. These areas included: 115.311 - Zero tolerance of
sexual abuse and sexual harassment; PREA coordinator; 115.313 - Supervision
and monitoring; 115.316 - Residents with disabilities and residents who are limited
English proficient; 115.317 - Hiring and promotion decisions; 115.321 - Evidence
protocol and forensic medical examinations; 115.322 - Policies to ensure referrals
of allegations for investigations; 115.331 - Employee training; 115.332 - Volunteer
and contractor training; 115.333 - Resident education; 115.335 - Specialized
training: Medical and mental health care; 115.351 - Resident reporting; 115.352 -
Exhaustion of administrative remedies; 115.353 - Resident access to outside
confidential support services and legal representation; 115.354 - Third-party
reporting; 115.361 - Staff and agency reporting duties; 115.362 - Agency protection
duties; 115.363 - Reporting to other confinement facilities; 115.371 - Criminal and
administrative agency investigations; 115.373 - Reporting to residents; 115.376 -
Disciplinary sanctions for staff; 115.381 - Medical and mental health screenings;
history of sexual abuse; 115.382 - Access to emergency medical and mental health
services; 115.386 - Sexual abuse incident reviews; 115.387 - Data collection;
115.388 - Data review for corrective action; 115.389 - Data storage, publication,
and destruction; and 115.401 - Frequency and scope of audits. Pineview completed
a corrective action plan and on August 15, 2022, had a final report that reported full
compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator noted 2022 being an "extremely difficult year for the
organization" noting concerns with rules changes, interpretations of the rules,
contract requirements, DHHS lack of response to 30-day notices, and pressure
from DHHS to accept youth in the program that did not meet the program treatment
requirements. The Chief Administrator noted trends for 2022 that included residents
learning they would not be restrained for certain behaviors which caused a "culture
of chaos with very few boundaries and significant fearfulness felt by several of our
residents". The Chief Administrator identified several special investigations that
occurred shortly after the new rules were implemented which led to rule violations
and corrective action plans. The Chief Administrator noted all corrective actions
have been completed and implemented successfully at this time. The Chief
Administrator noted another area of concern was with dental exams and finding a
4

provider that could meet the youth's dental needs in a timely manner. The Chief
Administrator reported that the facility made some changes organizationally by
discontinuing the abuse/neglect contract and opening a new program that is short
term with court ordered youth. The Chief Administrator reported the new program is
going very well so far this year.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff report they feel supported by administration. They all have reported
enjoying the new program that has been opened this year. The staff voiced
concerns about feeling they cannot always keep youth safe due to not being able to
stop them from running away.
The youth all reported feeling safe and well cared for. The youth reported being
able to go off campus and do activities. The youth did not report any concerns
about the program or treatment from staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility was completed and there were no concerns noted.
The facility is in good condition with no repairs needed. The menu is posted in both
houses and the food is prepped in the main kitchen and brought to the houses at
each mealtime. The bedrooms are clean and appropriately furnished. The
bathrooms are clean, the youth use the showers in the gymnasium which are clean
and appropriate.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
